lesson_subtitle: Making Connections Between Arithmetic Sequences and Linear Functions
lesson_description: In this lesson, students connect an arithmetic sequence in explicit form to a linear function in slope-intercept form. They prove that the common difference and the slope are always constant and equal. Students use first differences to determine whether a table represents a linear relationship and learn about average rate of change. They create a table of values and determine whether the sequences have the same slope between any two points.
learning_goals: I can relate the defining characteristics of an arithmetic sequence, the first term and common difference, and the defining characteristics of a linear function, the y-intercept and slope.
I can use algebraic properties to prove that the explicit formula for an arithmetic sequence is equivalent to the equation of a linear function.
I can connect the slope of a line to the average rate of change of a function.
essential_ideas: You can write the explicit formula of an arithmetic sequence in slope-intercept form.

The explicit formula of an arithmetic sequence, <math><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, includes the first term of the sequence, <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, and the common difference. The slope-intercept form of a linear function, <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, includes <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> and the slope.
You can use the average rate of change formula to calculate the unit rate over a given interval.

You can calculate the first differences of a table by subtracting consecutive output values when the input values have an interval of 1. When the first differences are constant, you can model the table of values with a linear function.
The arithmetic sequence's domain includes the counting numbers, while the linear function's domain includes all real numbers.
